sen.j: 蔵人（くろうど、藏人）は日本の律令制下の令外官の一つ。
sen.e: Kurodo refers to one of Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes) in Japan.
Kurodo refers to one of Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes) in Japan.
Kurodo refers to one of Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes) in Japan.

sen.j: 天皇の秘書的役割を果たした。
sen.e: It played a role of secretary.
The Kurodo played the role of secretary.
The Kurodo played the role of secretary.

sen.j: 唐名は侍中（じちゅう）、夕郎（せきろう）、夕拝郎（せきはいろう）。
sen.e: It was called jichu, sekiro or sekihairo in Tang China.
Kurodo was called jichu, sekiro or sekihairo in Tang China.
Kurodo was called jichu, sekiro or sekihairo in Tang China.

sen.j: 蔵人所は事務を行う場所のことで、内裏校書殿の北部に置かれた。
sen.e: Kurododokoro (the chamberlain's office) was a place to perform clerical work, and was established in the northern part of Kyoshoden (palace archives) in the Imperial Palace.
Kurododokoro (the chamberlain's office) was a place to perform clerical work, and was established in the northern part of Kyoshoden (palace archives) in the Imperial Palace.
Kurododokoro (the chamberlain's office) was a place to perform clerical work, and was established in the northern part of Kyoshoden Hall (Palace Archives) in the Imperial Palace.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: また、蔵人は百官名或いは人名の一つで、この場合は「くらんど」と読む。
sen.e: 蔵人, Chinese characters of kurodo, also refers to one of hyakkan na (a name taken after his/her or family's official rank) or person's name, and in this case, it was pronounced as 'Kurando.'
蔵人, Chinese characters of kurodo, also refers to one of hyakkan na (a name taken after his/her or family's official rank) or person's name, and in this case, it was pronounced as 'Kurando.'
蔵人, Chinese characters of kurodo, also refers to one of hyakkan na (a name taken after his or her family's official rank) or person's name, and in this case, it was pronounced as 'Kurando.'

sen.j: 大同 (日本)4年（809年）、平城天皇が嵯峨天皇に譲位し、平城上皇として平城京に移り住んだ。
sen.e: In 809, Emperor Heizei assigned his throne to Emperor Saga, and moved to Heijo-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara) as the Retired Emperor Heizei.
In 809, Emperor Heizei assigned his throne to Emperor Saga, and moved to Heijo-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara) as the Retired Emperor Heizei.
In 809, Emperor Heizei assigned his throne to Emperor Saga, and moved to Heijo-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara) as the Retired Emperor Heizei.

sen.j: この時、後宮の寵妃藤原薬子やその兄藤原仲成も同行したが、藤原薬子が天皇の秘書である内侍司の長官（尚侍）であった。
sen.e: At this time, his choki (a favorite mistress), FUJIWARA no Kusuko of kokyu, and her older brother, FUJIWARA no Nakanari accompanied him, but, FUJIWARA no Kusuko was in the position of kami (director) (naishinokami (or shoji; Principal Handmaid) of naishi no tsukasa (female palace attendants) which played a role of secretary to the emperor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At this time, his choki (a favorite mistress), FUJIWARA no Kusuko of kokyu, and her older brother, FUJIWARA no Nakanari accompanied him, but, FUJIWARA no Kusuko was in the position of kami (director) (naishinokami (or shoji; Principal Handmaid) of naishi no tsukasa (female palace attendants) which played a role of secretary to the emperor.

At this time, his choki (a favorite mistress), FUJIWARA no Kusuko of kokyu (empress's residence), and her older brother, FUJIWARA no Nakanari accompanied him, but, FUJIWARA no Kusuko was in the position of kami (director) (naishinokami (or shoji; Principal Handmaid) of naishi no tsukasa (female palace attendants) which played a role of secretary to the emperor.

sen.j: そのため、平安京にいた嵯峨天皇は秘書を欠いて書類事務に支障をきたした。
sen.e: Therefore, Emperor Saga who had no secretary had a problem in documentation and clerical work.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, Emperor Saga who had no secretary had a problem in documentation and clerical work.
Therefore, Emperor Saga who were in Heian-kyo without a secretary had a problem in documentation and clerical work.

sen.j: その上、薬子の変へと繋がる上皇との対立もあり、新たな秘書役として大同5年（810年）に藤原冬嗣と巨勢野足を蔵人頭に、清原真野らを蔵人に任命した。
sen.e: Furthermore, since there was a conflict with the Retired Emperor which brought about the Kusuko Incident, in 810, FUJIWARA no Fuyutsugu and KOZE no Notari were appointed as Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain), and Mano KIYOHARA was appointed as kurodo, as new secretaries.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Furthermore, since there was a conflict with the Retired Emperor which brought about the Kusuko Incident, in 810, FUJIWARA no Fuyutsugu and KOZE no Notari were appointed as Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain), and Mano KIYOHARA was appointed as kurodo, as new secretaries.

Furthermore, since there was a conflict with the Retired Emperor which brought about the Kusuko Incident, in 810, FUJIWARA no Fuyutsugu and KOZE no Notari were appointed as Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain), and Mano KIYOHARA was appointed as kurodo, as new secretaries.

sen.j: これがはじまりである。
sen.e: This was the start of a history of kurodo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This was the start of the history of the kurodo.
This was the start of the history of the kurodo.

sen.j: 平城上皇側に機密がもれないようにすることも目的であった。
sen.e: Such appointments were conducted also for the purpose of preventing secrets from being leaked to the side of the Retired Emperor Heizei.
Such appointments were conducted also for the purpose of preventing secrets from being leaked to the side of the Retired Emperor Heizei.
Such appointments were conducted also for the purpose of preventing secrets from being leaked to the side of the Retired Emperor Heizei.

sen.j: のち光孝天皇・宇多天皇にいたってその権威は強化され、組織も拡充されるにいたった。
sen.e: Thereafter, the authority was strengthened during the periods of Emperors Koko and Uda, and the organization was expanded.
Thereafter, the authority was strengthened during the periods of Emperors Koko and Uda, and the organization was expanded.
Thereafter, the authority was strengthened during the periods of Emperors Koko and Uda, and the organization was expanded.

sen.j: 蔵人所はもともと天皇家の家政機関として、書籍や御物の管理、また機密文書の取り扱いや訴訟を扱った。
sen.e: As a domestic governing institution of the Imperial Family, Kurododokoro was originally in charge of management of documents and gyobutsu (Imperial treasures), handling of confidential documents, and handling of suits.

As a domestic governing institution of the Imperial Family, Kurododokoro was originally in charge of management of documents and gyobutsu (Imperial treasures), handling of confidential documents, and handling of suits.

As a domestic governing institution of the Imperial Family, Kurododokoro was originally in charge of management of documents and gyobutsu (Imperial treasures), handling of confidential documents, and handling of suits.

sen.j: やがて、訴訟には関与しなくなるが、詔勅、上奏の伝達や、警護、事務、雑務等殿上人におけるあらゆる事を取り仕切る機関となった。
sen.e: Eventually, Kurododokoro stopped handling suits, but became an institution handling everything handled by tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) such as transmission of Shochoku (imperial edict) and Joso (report to the throne), guard, clerical work, routine tasks and so on.

Eventually, Kurododokoro stopped handling suits, but became an institution handling everything handled by tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) such as transmission of Shochoku (imperial edict) and Joso (report to the throne), guard, clerical work, routine tasks and so on.

Eventually, Kurododokoro stopped handling suits, but became an institution handling everything handled by tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) such as transmission of Shochoku (imperial edict) and Joso (report to the throne), guard, clerical work, routine tasks and so on.

sen.j: 平安時代中期になると内豎所・御匣殿・進物所・ 大歌所・楽所・作物所・御書所・一本御書所・内御書所・画所など「所」といわれる天皇家の家政機関一切をも取り扱うようになる。
sen.e: In the mid Heian period, Kurododokoro came to handle matters concerning all domestic governing institution of the Imperial Family which were called '-sho or dokoro' such as Naijudokoro (Royal Pages Office), Joganden, Shinmotsudokoro (Serving Office), Outadokoro (an organization that provided the education and management for ancient Japanese music, Uta, and traditional instruments), Gakusho (chamber of music), Tsukumodokoro (a palace office responsible for making accessories and furnishings), Goshodokoro (an office to maintain books inthe Imperial Court), Ippon-goshodokoro, Uchi no goshodokoro (the place that kept Emperor's books), Edokoro (Imperial office treating about pictures) and so on.

In the mid Heian period, Kurododokoro came to handle matters concerning all domestic governing institution of the Imperial Family which were called '-sho or dokoro' such as Naijudokoro (Royal Pages Office), Joganden, Shinmotsudokoro (Serving Office), Outadokoro (an organization that provided the education and management for ancient Japanese music, Uta, and traditional instruments), Gakusho (chamber of music), Tsukumodokoro (a palace office responsible for making accessories and furnishings), Goshodokoro (an office to maintain books inthe Imperial Court), Ippon-goshodokoro, Uchi no goshodokoro (the place that kept Emperor's books), Edokoro (Imperial office treating about pictures) and so on.

In the mid Heian period, Kurododokoro came to handle matters concerning all domestic governing institution of the Imperial Family which were called '-sho' or '-dokoro' such as Naijudokoro (Royal Pages Office), Mikushige-dono (the place handling clothes in the Imperial palace), Shinmotsudokoro (Serving Office), Outadokoro (an organization that provided the education and management for ancient Japanese music, Uta, and traditional instruments), Gakusho (chamber of music), Tsukumodokoro (a palace office responsible for making accessories and furnishings), Goshodokoro (an office to maintain books in the Imperial Court), Ippon-goshodokoro, Uchi no goshodokoro (the place that kept Emperor's books), Edokoro (Imperial office treating about pictures) and so on.
sen.cmt: ウェブに合わせて、原文・訳文を修正しました。

sen.j: たいていは弁官から1名が補任されて「頭弁（とうのべん）」と呼ばれ、もう1名は近衛中将から補任され「頭中将（とうのちゅうじょう）」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In most cases, one was selected and appointed among Benkan (officials of the dajokan), and was called 'Tono Ben' (chief of officials of the dajokan), and the other was selected and appointed among Konoe no chujo (middle captain of the palace guards), and was called 'Tono Chujo' (the first secretary's captain).

In most cases, one was selected and appointed among Benkan (officials of the dajokan), and was called 'Tono Ben,' and the other was selected and appointed among Konoe no chujo (middle captain of the palace guards), and was called 'Tono Chujo.'
